bug.short_desc: MBlocker block() prevents focusable elements to get the correct appearance

long_desc.thetext:
When MBlocker block() method is used, the focusable elements don't get any visual indication that they are currently focused. See the attached application; as soon as you comment the call to block(), things work as expected.
Note that the focus events are still correctly fired and received, however that does not trigger any changes in the appearance... I even checked the states object received by the Appearance system and states.focused is never set.
I am not sure what is exactly causing this but it is quite problematic; MBlocker especially can be useful with dialog windows such as the login I made in the attached app, but without focus, it's not very nice.
Created attachment 575 Test case (sample app)

to Fabian.
FYI, another MBlocker issue is bug #2713
to Chris, consult Fabian as needed.
Increase priority.
Accepted.
The "focus" event occurs, but the state for the appearance isn't set (the FocusHandler dosen't call the "visualizeFocus" method).

The fix for bug #2981 (rev. 20503) as also fixed this issue. The problem was that setting the root application to anonymous causes an issue with the FocusHandler. The FocusHandler hasn't received focus events, which sets the appearance for the widget.
Jean-Noel, could you please verify that this is also works for you and set the state to verified. Thanks Chris
-> CLOSED
mass renaming of 0.9 target to 1.0-beta1

Hi, I finally got around to testing this. This bug is actually not fixed at all (the changes you made to the other bug did not fix this). I updated the sample application testcase as it was not working properly anymore with Qx 1.0.
As you can see in the sample application, I create the blocker at a lower zIndex than my main login window. The login window appears fine, but is unable to receive focus events (or, more exactly the FocusHandler does not receive those).
I had a look at #2981. When you fix this make sure you don't do a regression with that other bug.
Created attachment 689 The updated test case (ok with 1.0).
Thanks, I will have a look.

I couldn't reproduce your issue. The appearance is set for the focused button. The only problem was that pressing the tab key has no effect. But this is correct, you call the block() method which stops key events (When the blocker gets these). If you will block the background from your logging window please use blockContent(). Here my changes to run this with your code: change "blocker.block();" to "blocker.blockContent(this.loginPanel.getZIndex()-1);".
Does this solve your issue?

I am not sure if what you say will help me solve my issue... In the test case I uploaded, probably. But I am actually using the blocker in an inline application where the blocker is a different inline root that another widget. The other widget is positioned before the blocker, since the inline DOM base element has a higher zindex.
Still, the tab key is blocked by the blocker. Let me try to see if I can figure it out.

OK, so I think there is still some bug or at least strange behavior, but I was able to get it working on my setup.
My setup is the following: I have two DOM elements that will serve as inline roots for Qx widgets. One has a zIndex of 5000, the second of 6000.
The one with a zIndex of 5000 will basically be used only as a blocker. However, when using block() it still blocks the tab events of the other widget. I guess it should not do that since the other widget is not a child of the blocker (it's an entirely different inline root).
Note that by using blockContent() on the blocker inline root, it works. *Any* value of zIndex for blockContent() is OK.
Maybe this is the expected behavior because only blockContent() takes into account the child (and zIndex, but here it does not matter) relationship, whereas I don't really understand how block() works - how is it able to stop events from a completely different widget (and completely different DOM hierarchy).
I would appreciate some explanations, as this is still a bit strange.
That's really strange, I will try to reproduce this issue with two inline roots.
I could reproduce the blocking problem in an inline application. I opened a separate bug #3223 for it, because this bug has an other issue, with has nothing to do with the appearance.
Oops! Wrong bug number in comment #17. I meant bug #3323.
Closed all bugs already shipped with a release.
